RN168, Km 0 Santa Fe 3000 Argentina Mesoporous silica (SBA-15) functionalized with different concentrations of sulfonic groups is used in the esterification of glycerine with fatty acids. This article addresses the effects of temperature, free fatty acids/glycerine ratio and catalyst concentration. It has been shown that high amounts of secondary products may be formed in this reaction system. Accordingly, this work also analyzes the effect of reaction conditions on this yield and presents a comparison with the effect obtained using homogeneous catalysts. Significant amounts of secondary products are also formed with liquid catalysts. The hydrophobic/hydrophilic behavior of the catalysts plays a key role both in the activity and selectivity to the desired products. A catalyst was prepared tuning the hydrophobicity of the surface in order to test this hypothesis, obtaining a higher activity than in the conventional catalyst. These results show the importance of designing catalysts with amphiphilic properties for this system. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Glycerine esterification Fatty acids Functionalized SBA-15 Hydrophobicity Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In order to overcome the difficulties of climate change and make biorefineries more efficient, the search for new processes that allow the reutilization of waste by-products has received considerable attention in recent years. This interest has been particularly focused on those by-products generated in industries based on renewable materials. The esterification of glycerine with free fatty acids is an example of such processes. This procedure uses as reactants the glycerine produced in the biodiesel industry and the fatty acids obtained in the same industry during the glycerine purification, or in the vegetable oil refining. The glycerine esterification with free fatty acids is useful in order to obtain second generation vegetable oils that can be employed to produce biodiesel which, in this case, is a second-generation biofuel obtained from waste materials [5]. In addition, this reaction is useful to decrease the acidity of vegetable oils and biodiesel [1,2]. The acid strength required to catalyze esterification is high; therefore, strong acids are needed, and either liquid or solid catalysts could be used. In a previous work [3], the use of liquid acids such as sulfuric acid (H2SO4), p-toluene sulfonic acid (PTSA) and methanesulfonic acid (MSA) was studied. It was shown that PTSA and MSA acids were the most active ones, being possible to reduce the acidity of pure FFA below 10 wt% before 60 min of reaction at 120 °C, using low concentrations of catalysts (0.35 eq/kg). When H2SO4 was used, a reaction time of 300 min was required to achieve similar conversions at the same reaction conditions. These large differences among the catalysts were attributed to the different chemical structures. MSA and PTSA acids have one polar group and one non-polar group in the molecule, giving them amphiphilic characteristics. Therefore, these compounds will preferentially locate at the glycerine-fatty acid interface, thus favoring the reaction rate. On the contrary, H2SO4 is a polar substance and is located within the glycerine phase. This concept is relevant regarding the design of solid acid catalysts. However, there are no reports concerning the use of catalysts with different hydrophobicity in this reaction even though it is particularly interesting since it involves two reactants with very different polarity, each one in a different phase. The use of solid catalysts in order to replace the more dangerous and corrosive liquid acids is a general objective, which would also simplify the stages of separation and recovery of the used catalysts. Nevertheless, it has been proved that the liquid catalysts can also be reused in the reaction since they accumulate in the glycerine phase, which is recycled to the reactor after separation from the reaction products just by centrifugation or decantation [3]. Several studies address this reaction using heterogeneous catalysts, such as ZnCl2 [4], 1.8% Zn–Al2O3 [5], deep-eutectic solvents [6], zinc acetate [7], NbOPO4 [8], SBA-2, SBA-12, SBA-15 and MCM-41 [9]. The use of SBA-15 functionalized with alkylsulfonic groups (SO3H-SBA15) has been studied in the synthesis of monoglycerides from lauric acid and glycerine [10–12]. These studies reported a 90% conversion of fatty acids at 6 h time-on-stream, with a selectivity to monoglycerides (MG) of 70% for a loading of 5 wt% of catalyst, molar ratio FFA:GOH 1:4, 160 °C and vacuum. These catalysts have also been compared with functionalized MCM-41 silica (SO3H-MCM-41), in the esterification of glycerine with lauric and palmitic acids for the synthesis of MG [13,14]. Alrouh et al. [13] tested these catalysts to reduce the acidity of olive-pomace oil, following the conversion of palmitic and oleic acids, the reaction conditions being 110 °C, molar ratio FFA:GOH 1:6, and 2 mol% of sulfonic acid groups with respect to oleic acid, for 24 h. These authors reported selectivities to MG of 40% and fatty acid conversions of 90% with SO3H-MCM-41, while the MG selectivity was 12% with SO3H-SBA15, reaching similar conversion values. On the other hand, Jeenpadiphat et al. [14], under the same reaction conditions, reported maximum yields to TG of 30.5% with oleic acid conversions of 81%, in 360 min with a SO3H-MCM-41 catalyst while when using a SO3H-SBA-15 catalyst the values of TG selectivity and conversion were 37.8% and 88.8%, respectively, at 120 min. The SBA-type mesoporous silicas have also been studied functionalized with other acid groups, such as 12-tungstophosphoric acid [15] and sulfated zirconia [10,16]. In general, the reaction was carried out at temperatures above 100 °C, and up to 200 °C approximately. Zuo et al. [26] studied the SBA-15 functionalized with several different acid groups in the transesterification of soybean oil with 1-butanol. Propyl-SO3H, arene-SO3H and perfluoro-SO3H groups have been used, the latter being completely deactivated due to the leaching of the active groups. However, a more detailed study of the reaction has not been carried out, limiting itself to the use of a single type of fatty acid and the production of monoglycerides, without mentioning overall yields of the reaction and the presence of secondary reactions. None of the articles cited above [9–14, 23] mentioned the problem of secondary products formation which usually leads to dark color products, as mentioned in the review by Hermida et al. [24], and presented in detail in our previous work [3] using homogeneous catalysts. This is a key issue of these processes, since as recently discussed, the formation of secondary products is a major problem in this reacting system when using homogeneous catalysts [3] . It is important to compare the yield between homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts in order to advance towards a process optimization working under conditions in which the secondary products formation is minimized. The deactivation mechanisms of solid catalysts have not been addressed, and the reuse tests have been carried out in few studies and were limited to few cycles in order to verify the stability of the materials. Another concept used to design better catalysts for glycerine esterification is related to the hydrophobicity modification, trying to avoid water adsorption and thus favoring the direct reaction. Pérez-Pariente et al. [9] studied the sulfonic functionalized MCM-41 in the esterification of glycerine with lauric and oleic acid, and addressed the effect of changing the hydrophobicity of the surface introducing methyl groups by co-condensation. They found an improvement in the activity towards the monoglycerides as hydrophobicity increased, suggesting that the reason was the lower water adsorption capacity of the hydrophobic catalysts. Shih-Yuan Chen et al. [23] also studied the effect of hydrophobicity on the surface of functionalized SBA-15 in the esterification of oleic acid with methanol. These authors also found a lower impact of the presence of water in the initial reaction rate when using the catalyst with hydrophobic surface. Manayil et al. [25] prepared SBA-15 functionalized with propylsulfonic groups adding octyltrimetoxysilane to tune the hydrophobicity, and tested the catalysts in the esterification of acetic acid with methanol. Using the Inverse Gas Chromatography technique, they concluded that the decrease in polarity of the surface (increase in hydrophobicity) led to a decrease in the free energy of methanol adsorption. It is important to highlight that several reports studied the catalysts with modified hydrophobicity in monophasic systems. They considered it especially important and interesting to address the amphiphilic materials in biphasic systems since in this case the catalyst could be located at the interface, thus improving the catalytic activity as demonstrated in the case of the homogeneous p-toluene sulfonic acid catalyst [3]. This approach is applied in the present investigation. Therefore, in this work propyl sulfonic functionalized SBA-15 materials are tested in order to find the optimal reaction conditions that maximize yields, and also reduce energy requirements and processing costs. The secondary products are quantified and compared with those obtained with liquid acid catalysts. This information is useful in order to properly select the more efficient catalyst to esterify glycerine with free fatty acids. In addition, the effect of changing the hydrophobicity of a functionalized SBA-15 is also addressed, pointing towards the amphiphilic behavior to explain the results. These are important contributions of this research. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reactants Pure free fatty acids (FFA) (acidity no less than 98 wt%) were obtained in our laboratory from soybean oil. Anhydrous glycerine (Cicarelli PA, 99.5%) was used as reactant. 2.2 Synthesis of mesoporous silica SBA-15 The sulfonic-functionalized materials used in this paper have been synthesized by a one-step method, following a procedure similar to one already described in the literature [17]. The modifications introduced to this procedure have been presented elsewhere [18]. Typically, Pluronic © P123 (4.5 g, Sigma Aldrich) was dissolved overnight in 1.9 N hydrochloric acid (140 ml) under stirring. Then the solution was heated to 313 K and tetraethoxy-silane (TEOS, Sigma-Aldrich) was added. After a prehydrolysis step (1 h), 3-mercaptopropyl trimethoxy-silane (MPTMS, Sigma Aldrich) and H2O2 (100 vol., Biopack) were added. After 24 h of ripening, the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave and aged at 403 K for another 24 h. Finally, the material was vacuum filtered, washed with distilled water and dried. The surfactant was then removed by extraction in a Soxhlet device with acidic ethanol (200 ml commercial ethanol plus 2 ml commercial hydrochloric acid) for 8 h. The amounts of TEOS and MPTMS were adjusted in order to total 0.046 mol, varying the proportion of the latter in order to achieve different loads of acid sites. The materials were labeled SBA(X), with X representing the mol% of MPTMS referred to the overall quantity of MPTMS and TEOS added, and ranged between 5 and 15. Hydrophobic SBA-15 catalysts were prepared according to the aforementioned procedure, employing 0.0414 mol of TEOS in the prehydrolysis, then adding 0.0046 mol of MPTMS together with 0.0023 mol of methoxytrimethylsilane (Sigma Aldrich) and H2O2. The resulting material was labeled SBA(10)H. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Nitrogen sortometry was carried out using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 equipment. Prior to the adsorption, the samples were evacuated at 423 K and 10−5 Pa vacuum during 8 h. Then, adsorption–desorption isotherms were recorded at 77 K in a relative pressure range between 10−3 and 0.975. Total pore volume was measured according to the Gurvich rule at the P/Pº = 0.975, and surface area was estimated with the BET model [19]. The pore-size distribution was calculated employing the Broekhoff and de Boer (BdB) method [20]. It is worth mentioning that surfaces with functional groups do not provide uniform physisorption sites and, therefore, do not fully comply with the hypotheses of the BET model; thus, the values of surface area must be considered approximate and indicative. Structural information was obtained by small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) in a SAXS/WAXS system Xenocs Xeuss 1.0 equipped with an X-ray detector PILATUS 100 K (Dectris, Switzerland) and a Cu Kα X-ray source (1.54178 Å wavelength). Measurements were performed in transmission mode, at room temperature, with a voltage of 50 kV and a current of 0.6 mA and a distance between sample and detector of 1360 mm. S and Si content in the solids were measured by Energy-214 dispersive X-ray fluorescence (ED-XRF), using a Shimadzu equipment, model EDX-720, and working in the energy dispersion mode. X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed in a SPECS multitechnique instrument, model XR50, and a PHOIBOS 150 hemispherical analyzer in fixed analyzer transmission (FAT) mode. The spectrum in the case of the SBA(10) catalyst was obtained with a pass energy of 30 eV and a Mg anode operated at 200 W, while in the case of the SBA(10)H a monochromatic Al source was used. The pressure during the measurement was less than 2 × 10−9 mbar. The sample was pressed and supported on a sample holder, and then treated under vacuum for 10 min at 120 °C and finally evacuated in ultrahigh vacuum for 2 h. Spectra were referenced to adventitious carbon C 1 s signal at 284.8 eV. The amount of acid sites in the catalysts was determined by potentiometric titration. Typically, 30 mg of solid were suspended with 40 ml acetonitrile in a 50 ml Erlenmeyer flask under vigorous stirring and kept until potential stabilization. Then, a solution of 0.01 M butylamine in acetonitrile was pumped at a rate of 0.10 ml/min into the flask while potential was recorded until values reached a clear plateau. Potential was measured with an electrode of LiCl saturated in ethanol connected to a Metrohm 913 pH meter. The equivalence point was determined by a modified Gran linearization method [21]. The concentration of acid sites was expressed as mol of acid sites per gram of catalyst. The acid sites density was calculated as the ratio of the acid sites concentration and the specific surface and expressed as (sites/nm2). Thermogravimetric analyses were performed in a Mettler-Toledo TGA/SDTA851e equipment. Approximately 10 mg of sample were loaded into an alumina crucible and heated with a ramp of 12 K min−1 from 298 to 1023 K, then maintaining the final temperature for 10 min. Heating was carried out under air flow of 50 cm3 min−1. Mass loss as a function of time and temperature (thermogram, TGA) was recorded, from which its derivative was obtained (DTG) as well as the single differential thermal analysis (SDTA). Prior to measurements, some samples were dried overnight at 313 K and then equilibrated with moist air for 72 h, in order to later assess the water sorption. An optical microscope (Arcano XSZ 100 BNT) was used to observe the catalyst in the reaction media. Biodiesel was used instead of FFA, since the latter solidifies at room temperature and does not make it possible to obtain the pictures of the reaction media. The polarities of biodiesel and FFA are similar. The mixture of biodiesel and glycerine (molar ratio 1:1) was put in a vial, the catalyst was added (3 wt%) and agitated during a few minutes. A drop was taken from this system and observed with the optical microscope. In addition, the amphiphilic behavior of the hydrophobic version of the functionalized SBA-15 catalyst was observed in an Inverted Confocal Microscope Leica model TCS SP8, equipped with a laser of 488 nm, 514 nm, 552 nm and 638 nm wavelengths. It had objective lens for air, and for immersion in water and oil. The microscope also had two channels of spectral detection between 350 nm and 800 nm, and one of transmitted light, all of them with photomultipliers. The technique of detection of fluorophores was followed, using rhodamine as fluorescent dye. The catalysts were loaded in a vial containing water and n-dodecane, mixed, and then loaded in the microscope. 2.4 Esterification reaction The reaction was carried out in a glass batch reactor with magnetic stirrer, connected with a vacuum pump. The fatty acids were loaded into the reactor and heated to the reaction temperature. Then, the catalyst mixed with glycerine was poured into the reactor. In order to eliminate the water produced during the reaction, vacuum was applied, starting with 600 mmHg for the first 2 h and then increasing the vacuum to 755 mmHg. The reason for this sequence is to avoid a very high vacuum at the beginning of the reaction, otherwise foaming occurs. The reaction temperature was varied between 393 and 433 K. Selected experiments were carried out working under reflux conditions to evaluate the effect of water on the reaction kinetics, particularly in order to assess the influence of the hydrophobicity of the catalyst. Then, the catalyst was added in concentrations of 0.6, 1.2, 2.0 and 3.0 wt% referred to the total mass of the reaction mixture. The esterification of glycerine (GOH) with pure FFA was studied for the following FFA:GOH molar ratios: (i) the stoichiometric ratio towards the formation of monoglycerides (1:1), (ii) the stoichiometric ratio towards the formation to triglycerides (3:1), (iii) an excess of glycerine using a ratio 1:3. The experiments were carried out loading the same total mass of reactants in each of them, using in all cases the same reactor volume, stirring speed and magnetic bar, in order to have the same fluid dynamic conditions in all cases. In order to determine the precision of the composition measurements obtained during the reaction, selected experiments have been replicated under different conditions. Two experiments were replicated twice, and another one was replicated 3 times. The average percentage error was thus calculated for each measurement, and the standard deviation was determined. Using these results, the 95% confidence intervals were calculated. These intervals were 5% in the acidity value obtained by volumetric analysis and 2.5% in the case of the compositions obtained by chromatographic analysis. In order to calculate the selectivity to each compound in the FFA conversion in the present system, there is an important limitation, which is the presence of secondary products of as yet unknown composition. Therefore, it is not possible to know how many mols of FFA are converted to these products and the precise calculation of selectivities is not possible. However, it is possible to obtain an approximate value using the mass concentration, and obtaining a selectivity as follows: Si = [Ci / (CMG + CDG + CTG + CSP)] * 100 Where Si is the selectivity % of product i, and CMG, CDG, CTG, and CSP are the concentrations in wt% of MG, DG, TG and secondary products (SP), respectively. 2.4.1 Sampling and analysis Small aliquots of the reaction mixture were taken during the run, typically of 6 h. Each sample was centrifuged in order to separate the catalyst and glycerine from the oily phase containing the fatty acids and glycerides formed, and the following analyses were carried out on this non-polar phase: 1. FFA, i.e. the acidity expressed as (g of oleic acid/100 g), following the UNE-EN 14104 standard. The sample was dissolved in a mixture of toluene/ethanol (50:50) and titrated with KOH dissolved in isopropanol. 2. Mono-, di-, and tri-glycerides (MG, DG, TG respectively), and FFA were determined by GC, according to the UN-EN 14105 standard. The method was adjusted in order to have calibrations valid in different ranges of concentrations of the glycerides and FFA. The FFA were determined using these two procedures in order to increase the reliability of the analysis. Preliminary analyses of the reaction samples carried out to obtain information regarding the nature of the secondary products were carried out both by mass spectrometry (Perkin Elmer GC-MS Clarus 600) and FTIR. Typically, to obtain the FTIR spectrum, a drop of the reaction products was mixed with KBr in a mortar and later pressed in order to obtain a self-supporting wafer. The experiments were carried out in a Shimadzu IR Prestige 21 equipment equipped with a high-energy ceramic source and a LiTaO3 high-sensitivity pyroelectric detector. Spectra were recorded at room temperature and were obtained as the average of 60 scans. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The properties of the catalysts are summarized in Table 1. S/Si ratios measured by XRF show an incorporation of the functional groups of approximately 80% of the theoretical values. The amount of acid sites was proportional to the S content for every solid. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts (presented in the Supplementary data, Fig. S1. A) were of type IV according to IUPAC classification, which corresponds to mesoporous structures. The hysteresis loops were of type H1, with parallel branches associated with cylindrical mesopores. Derived properties are presented in Table 1. The BET area was higher for higher MPTMS loads, except in the case of the SBA(15) material that presented lower pore volume and pore diameter. All the synthesized materials presented BET surface areas in the 500–700 m2g−1 range. Although trends can be observed among solids with different functional groups and different loads, they lay between the variability of the calculation. It must be taken into account that the BET model does not consider inhomogeneities on the surface such as roughness and that the presence of functional groups and obtained surface area values are indicative and subject to errors. Fig. S1. B shows the pore size distributions obtained after applying the BdB method to the N2 desorption isotherms. For SBA(5) and SBA(10) catalysts the pore size distribution was sharp and centered around 10 nm. However, in the case of the SBA(15) catalyst, the pore size distribution was broad and bimodal, with peaks around 6.5 and 8.5 nm. SAXS analyses ( Fig. 1) show the expected pattern for solids with a hexagonal pore arrangement. For SBA(15), the peaks were broader with a shoulder at higher angles, indicating a partially disordered material. This is consistent with the results obtained with the isotherms, the pore-size distribution and the pore volume. These results show that with the higher load of MPTMS (SBA(15)), the ordering of the structure was affected. It has been previously reported that increments in the amount of MPTMS added in co-condensation syntheses lead to perturbations in the sol-gel processes involved in the formation of the solids, thus resulting in poorly-ordered materials [22]. 3.2 Influence of reaction conditions In this section the effects of different variables such as temperature, concentration and type of catalyst, and reactant molar ratio, are analyzed. Since the reaction tests were carried out applying high levels of vacuum in all runs in order to remove the water from the reaction media to displace the equilibrium, the water concentration was measured in a number of experiments to be sure of its concentration. At 2 h of reaction time, the water concentration was always well below 100 ppm. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that its concentration has no impact in the conversion level. 3.2.1 Effect of reaction temperature The effect of temperature on the esterification reaction was studied with the three solid catalysts. Additionally, a blank test (without catalyst) was performed, since the acidity generated by the presence of FFA (weak acids) may have a small catalytic effect. The conditions used in these experiments were molar ratio FFA:GOH = 1:1, catalyst concentration 1.2 wt% referred to the total mass of the reaction mixture, under vacuum as explained in the experimental part. The reaction temperature was varied between 393 K and 433 K. Fig. 2 shows the FFA concentration as a function of time in the presence of different catalysts at different reaction temperatures. It is clearly seen that increasing the temperature increases the reaction rate as indicated by the lower final FFA concentration at higher temperatures. At 393 K there was a negligible difference in conversion between the catalysts and the non-catalyzed reaction (Fig. 2. A). As shown in Table 1, the acid sites density was almost double in SBA(10) compared to SBA(5), being 0.81 sites/nm2 for the former and 0.41 sites/nm2 for the latter. Nevertheless, the activity was very similar between both catalysts at 393 K, with a slight difference in the activity at long reaction times. Moreover, the activity of these catalysts is essentially the same as that obtained without catalyst, i.e. under autocatalytic conditions. At 413 K (Fig. 2. B), SBA(5) performed similarly to the autocatalytic test, reaching conversions of 53.2% and 52.7% after 360 min, respectively. SBA(10) gave higher conversions from 60 min onwards, reaching 64.0% conversion at 360 min. Despite its higher amount of acid sites, SBA(15) did not perform better than SBA(10), reaching 60.0% conversion after 360 min. This behavior is explained by taking into account the textural characterization of the catalysts. As already discussed, the highest load of sulfonic groups led to a material with poorer ordering and smaller pores, possibly resulting in partially inaccessible sites as well as diffusional limitations. The effect of temperature was quite marked at 433 K (Fig. 2. C). The SBA(5) catalyst showed low activity after 240 min of reaction and then conversion increased compared with the autocatalytic reaction. The SBA(10) and SBA(15) catalysts showed similar activity between them and significantly higher than SBA(5), the conversions being 95% and 93% for SBA(10) and SBA(15), at 360 min. The catalyst with 10% sulfonic groups showed better conversions than in the case of the catalyst containing 15% in spite of its lower amount of acid sites. This result was observed both at 413 and 433 K, and as above explained, it is attributed to the poorer ordering of the SBA(15) catalyst. Thus, the optimum load was selected as the one corresponding to the nominal S/Si load of 10% (SBA(10)). Regarding the temperature, 433 K was adopted. Further tests were carried out using these experimental conditions. 3.2.2 Effect of catalyst loading In order to investigate the effect of catalyst loading, the following concentrations of the SBA(10) catalyst were used: 1.2; 2 and 3 wt%. The experiments were carried out at 433 K, with a molar ratio FFA:GOH 1:1 and applying vacuum as in the previous experiments. The results obtained are shown in Fig. 3. There is a significant effect of catalyst concentration on the reaction rate. For a catalyst load of 3 wt%, a conversion of 93% was obtained at 60 min. In the case of a catalyst load of 2 wt%, to obtain a similar conversion, e.g., 90%, a reaction time of 180 min was necessary, while with 1.2 wt% to obtain this conversion of 90%, 360 min were necessary. The initial reaction rate was calculated using the slope obtained at time zero of each curve presented in Fig. 3. Within the experimental errors, these slopes were practically equal to those corresponding to the segment that connected the initial acidity and the acidity measured at 30 min. The reaction rate was calculated as grams of FFA converted per minute per gram of catalyst loaded to the reactor (g FFA/g catalyst.min). The initial rates obtained in these experiments were 0.45, 0.40 and 0.46 g FFA/g catalyst.min when using 1.2, 2 and 3 wt% catalyst, respectively. These results show that the intrinsic activity is practically constant when changing the amount of catalyst and, therefore, there is an increase in the reaction rate proportional to the increase in the amount of catalyst. 3.2.3 Product distribution Fig. 4 shows the evolution of mono-, di-, and triglycerides as a function of time obtained with the SBA(10) catalyst. The reaction conditions were: catalyst load of 1.2 and 3 wt%, at 433 K, a molar ratio FFA:GOH 1:1 and the same vacuum sequence as above described. Fig. 4 A shows the typical evolution of products formed in a sequential mechanism. The MG are primary products, while DG and TG are formed in a second and third reaction steps, respectively. Because of this, both products display an induction period with a slope equal to zero at time zero. TG appears in appreciable concentrations after 1 h of reaction. The maximum in the concentration of MG is well defined, while in the case of the DG the maximum is not reached during the 360 min of reaction. A similar behavior is observed in the case of using 3 wt% of SBA(10) (Fig. 4. B), although in this case, the changes occur at a much faster rate. The main product is DG, reaching a concentration of 37 wt% at one hour of reaction. A key issue that needs to be analyzed is the formation of secondary products. The concentration of these products can be calculated as the difference between 100 and the sum of the concentrations of the compounds (FFA+MG+DG+TG). In this calculation, it is taken into account that the main compounds are in the organic phase, and the amount of glycerine dissolved in this phase is negligible. This calculation can be carried out using the data shown in Fig. 4. For example, at a catalyst concentration of 1.2 wt% (Fig. 4. A), the sum of the known compounds is 81 wt% at 2 h and 67 wt% at 6 h. On the other hand, when using 3 wt% of catalyst the sum of (FFA+MG+DG+TG) is 60 wt% at 1 h. The concentration of the secondary products increases as a function of time, and when working with a higher catalyst load. It has to be highlighted that this low yield has been neglected in most publications, and it is important to work in a proper catalyst design and process conditions to minimize this problem. Fig. S2 (Supplementary material) shows the chromatograms of samples corresponding to the analyses presented in Fig. 4.B. It can be observed that as the reaction progresses, other compounds that are the products of secondary reactions begin to appear. Four zones with peaks that correspond to the secondary products are indicated, approximately at 8 min of retention time (before the FFA), at 18–20 min (after the MG), at 25–27 min (after the DG), and after the TG (31 min). These compounds are different from those found in the case of using homogeneous catalysts [3], since in this case there were no unidentified peaks in the GC analysis. Furthermore, the samples from the heterogeneous reactions never showed a dark coloration, as was the case when using liquid acids such as sulfuric, methanesulfonic, and p-toluene sulfonic (Fig. S3). This indicates that the nature of the secondary compounds is not exactly the same when carrying out the reaction with homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysts. It has to be mentioned that in both cases the reacting system has two phases, the glycerine-rich phase, and the organic phase in which the FFA, MG, DG and TG are present. The liquid catalysts and the SBA catalysts are concentrated in the glycerine phase. The selectivities calculated as explained in Section 2.4 are presented in Fig. S4. The results obtained with the three solid catalysts and the PTSA are shown. The molar ratio FFA/GOH used in these experiments was 1:1. The main product is DG in the case of the SBA(5), and MG in the other three catalysts (SBA(10), SBA(15), PTSA). Even though the SBA(5) and the PTSA catalysts were loaded in such a way of having the same amount of acid sites, the product distribution was significantly different. It took 240 min for SBA(5) to reach the 50% conversion, while in the case of the PTSA it was reached in 30 min. This higher rate of FFA consumption observed with the PTSA, and the fact that more MG are obtained with this catalyst, indicates that the ratio of the kinetic constants of the first step (forming MG) and the second step (forming DG) is higher for PTSA than in the case of the SBA(5). Fig. S5 shows selectivities obtained with SBA(10) and PTSA at 95% conversion. Comparing Figs. S4 and S5, it can be observed that as the conversion proceeds, the concentration of secondary products increases more in the SBA(10) catalyst than in the case of the PTSA, showing that this homogeneous catalyst is more selective towards the desired products. 3.2.4 Effect of Free fatty acids/Glycerine molar ratio The effect of the FFA:GOH molar ratio was studied with 2 wt% of SBA(10) at 433 K under vacuum conditions. Results are shown in Fig. 5.A. The final conversion increases as this ratio decreases from 3 (3:1) to 0.33 (1:3), as indicated by a higher final acidity in the former. For a ratio FFA:GOH = 3:1, the system seems to stabilize in intermediate conversions, since the glycerine is in stoichiometric proportions towards triglycerides formation, reaching a final acidity of 40 wt%. When increasing the proportion of glycerine, the conversion increases, reaching a final acidity of 5 and 2 wt% when using an FFA:GOH molar ratio of 1:1 and 1:3, respectively. The esterification of glycerine with fatty acids is a reversible reaction. Therefore, it can be expected that an excess of glycerine would produce a displacement of the reaction towards the products, increasing the conversion of FFA. Nonetheless, glycerine and FFA are practically immiscible and form two phases during the reaction. The catalyst is mostly hydrophilic due to the presence of surface silanols and it disperses preferentially in the glycerine-rich phase. MG, DG and TG accumulate in the FFA-rich phase (organic phase), while the water dissolves preferentially in the glycerine-rich phase. Since the water is continuously eliminated from the reacting system by working under vacuum conditions and the other compounds are practically absent in the glycerine rich phase, the concentration of glycerine in this phase is essentially constant, with a molar fraction close to one. Thus, the concentration of glycerine in the organic phase, which is very small throughout the whole reaction, is constant as well. This means that there should be no effect of the FFA:GOH ratio from the equilibrium and kinetic point of view. However, the initial reaction rates calculated as above explained (Section 3.2.2), using the curves shown in Fig. 5. A, are different and present the following tendency as a function of the FFA:GOH molar ratio: 3:1 > 1:1 > 1:3. Since, as above explained the concentration of reactants is not affected by the changes of their initial ratio, this difference in kinetics is attributed to the higher effective concentration of the catalyst, which is accumulated in the glycerine-rich phase. In this case, the volume of this phase is smaller than in the case of using molar ratios 1:1 and 1:3. When using the FFA:GOH molar ratio of 1:3, the volume of glycerine is the largest and, correspondingly, the catalyst is more diluted and the initial reaction rate is the lowest. To support this explanation, the values of these rates for each FFA:GOH ratio are presented in Table 2, together with the calculated catalyst concentration in the glycerine phase. Taking as a basis 100 g of FFA, for each FFA:GOH ratio used in this set of experiments, the corresponding amounts of glycerol and catalyst were calculated. Then the concentration of catalyst was obtained assuming that it is present almost exclusively in the glycerine phase and its quantity in the organic phase is negligible. It can be observed that the initial reaction rate is the lowest in the case with the largest proportion of glycerine (FFA:GOH = 1:3), and on the other hand, the initial rate is the highest (0.75 g FFA/g catalyst.min) in the case of using the minimum proportion of glycerine (FFA:GOH = 3:1). When these initial reaction rates are plotted as a function of the aforementioned catalyst concentrations in the glycerine phase (Fig. 5. B), a perfect linear correlation is found. This fact reinforces the hypothesis that the influence of the FFA:GOH ratio on the reaction kinetics is attributable to a catalyst dilution effect. There is another important issue that should be highlighted. Table 2 shows that the amount of catalyst loaded per 100 g of FFA is the lowest in the case of an FFA:GOH 3:1 and, however, the reaction rate is the highest. This means that decreasing the proportion of glycerine loaded to the reactor largely improves the overall process efficiency. Even though this is a very important concept in the process design, it is necessary to point out that during the reaction there are two important effects. On one hand, the catalyst is concentrated as the glycerine is consumed, having a positive effect on the reaction rate. On the other hand, the reactant (FFA) decreases its concentration due to the dilution with MG, DG, and TG, decreasing the reaction rate. The overall effect during the reaction has been observed to be a decrement of the rate as a function of time. Regarding the effects that the reaction advance has on the overall kinetics in this system, there is another important change that has to be kept in mind. As the reaction proceeds, the concentration of FFA in the organic phase decreases, while MG, DG, and TG accumulate in this phase, increasing its viscosity. Since the catalyst is present in the glycerine-rich phase (the polar phase), the reactant has to diffuse through a medium of increasing viscosity to reach the interface in which there is a low concentration of the hydrophilic catalyst and, therefore, this rheological change has an important negative effect on the reaction rate. Fig. 6 shows the distribution of mono-, di-, and triglycerides for different FFA:GOH ratios at 240 min. In the case of the reaction carried out using the stoichiometric FFA:GOH ratio towards triglycerides formation (3:1), the main products are di- and triglycerides, with a very low concentration of monoglycerides (below 0.2%). In the other extreme, with a large excess of glycerine (FFA:GOH = 1:3), the main products are diglycerides and monoglycerides, with a low concentration of triglycerides, approximately 5 wt%. In the case of the FFA:GOH ratio of 1:1 the three groups of compounds appear, the diglycerides being the main product again. This is a remarkable feature, because it enables the design of the process according to the needs of the biorefinery, in order to obtain monoglycerides or triglycerides, in all cases mixed with diglycerides. The secondary products formed in these experiments were also quantified as above explained. In Fig. 6 it can be observed that the sum of (FFA+MG+DG+TG) decreases in the order 3:1 > 1:1 ∼ 1:3. It has to be taken into account that the conversion is lower in the case of the 3:1 ratio. The amount of secondary products formed in these experiments is approximately 40% in the case of the 1:1 and 1:3 ratios, and 15% for a ratio of 3:1 (see Fig. 6). 3.2.5 Comparison of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts In this section, the performance of the solid catalysts used in the present study is compared with that obtained using p-toluene sulfonic acid (PTSA). This catalyst was selected since in a previous study it showed very good activity [3]. The experiment carried out with 3 wt% of SBA(10) was taken as reference and different concentrations of PTSA were tested in order to obtain a similar evolution of acidity as a function of time. This concentration resulted to be 0.1 wt% of PTSA. The reaction conditions were the following: 433 K, FFA:GOH molar ratio 1:1, under vacuum (2 h at 60 cmHg and then at 76 cmHg). The results are shown in Fig. 7.A. The two catalysts show a similar evolution of acidity as a function of time. The number of acid sites used in the case of the PTSA was 0.45 mmol/100 g mixture, while in the case of the solid catalyst the amount of acid sites was 2.53 mmol/100 g mixture, i.e., five times higher. In conclusion, the intrinsic activity of the acid sites present in the PTSA is five times higher than in the case of the acid sites present in the SBA(10). As previously discussed [3], the PTSA has amphiphilic properties, and concentrates at the glycerine-FFA interface, thus improving the catalytic activity. The SBA catalysts used in the present study has hydrophilic surface and therefore it concentrates in the glycerine-rich phase. On the other hand, the accessibility of the acid sites present in the solid catalysts is restricted due to the pore system. Fig. 7 B shows the comparison between the PTSA and the SBA(5) catalysts, loaded to the reactor in such a way as to have exactly the same amount of acid sites, namely 0.45 mmol/100 g of reacting mixture. The difference between both catalysts in the activity for FFA conversion is considerable. While the PTSA needs 90 min to reach a concentration of FFA below 5 wt%, the SBA(5) reaches 28 wt% FFA in 360 min. Again, the difference in intrinsic activities between the homogeneous and the heterogeneous catalyst is remarkable. Fig. 8 A shows the evolution of the FFA and the product distribution obtained with 0.1 wt% of PTSA. The main products are DG and MG, having similar concentrations between them, while TG is obtained in very low concentrations. In the case of the solid catalyst, the MG yield was much smaller than the DG yield (see Fig. 4. B). A very important difference between these catalysts is the increase in the amount of secondary products. In the case of the solid catalyst the sum of glycerides formed plus the unconverted fatty acids decreases as a function of time. Fig. 8. B shows that as the reaction progresses, the concentration of secondary reactions products increases, as indicated by the continuous decrease of the (FFA+MG+DG+TG) amount. In the case of the SBA(10) catalyst, for a conversion of 92%, which was achieved at 60 min (Fig. 4. B), the sum of (FFA+MG+DG+TG) was 67%, while in the case of the PTSA catalyst at the same reaction time and a similar conversion of 93% (Fig. 8. B) the sum gave 80%. In conclusion, the homogeneous catalyst is more effective than the heterogeneous one. Not only is it more active at equal number of acid sites, but also the selectivity to the desired products is higher. These results suggest that an improvement in the solid catalyst formulation for this reaction system should include the incorporation of amphiphilic properties in the support. 3.3 Hydrophobic catalysts 3.3.1 Catalyst characterization In this section, the best performing solid catalyst (SBA(10)) is compared with a SBA-15 catalyst containing the same amount of sulfonic groups, but also trimethylsilane groups which confer hydrophobicity. The SBA(10)H hydrophobic material presented similar nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore-size distribution as SBA(10) (Fig. S1, Supplementary material), resulting in comparable values of the textural properties (Table 1). Sulfur incorporation and amount of acid sites were also congruent. It is important to point out that the acid sites concentration (mmol/g) in both catalysts is essentially the same and, therefore, there should be no effect of acidity of the catalysts SBA(10) and SBA(10)H on the catalytic activities. Thermogravimetric analyses after water saturation ( Fig. 9) showed two major weight losses: one associated with water around 363 K and another attributed to functional groups around 763 K. SDTA curves exhibited an endothermic peak in the first region, indicating a desorption, and an exothermic peak in the second region, consistent with a decomposition. The weight of the sample after the water desorption (mass of dry solid) was taken as reference. It can be noted that the incorporation of hydrophobic groups led to a reduction in water uptake from 1.22 to 1.01 g of water per g of dry catalyst. The SDTA curves also showed qualitatively a smaller endothermic peak for water desorption for SBA(10)H. Regarding the functional groups, the decomposition around 763 K indicates that all the mercaptan precursors were oxidized to their sulfonic form. Weight losses in this region were 12.9% for SBA(10) and 15.7% for SBA(10)H (both referred to the dry mass), where the latter includes the acid groups as well as the hydrophobic ones. Fig. S6 shows the XPS analyses obtained with SBA(10) and SBA(10)H catalysts. Both spectra are equivalent, showing that there are no modifications in the chemical state of the sulfonic groups due to the incorporation of methyl groups on the surface. Both spectra show signals corresponding to S 2p in sulfonic groups (binding energy around 168.8 eV). Silicon was detected only in one chemical state, with binding energies associated with SiO2 (153.9 eV for Si 2 s and 102.8 eV for Si 2p). These signals indicate that there is a single phase of sulfonic-functionalized silica in both catalysts, since they could not be deconvoluted into separate contributions. Fig. S6 shows small peaks at lower BE of all the peaks identified in the spectrum of the SBA(10) catalyst. As indicated in the Experimental section, the spectrum of SBA(10)H was obtained with a monochromatic Al source and in the case of SBA(10), it was obtained with a non-monochromatic Mg source. The latter produces a small amount of radiation of higher photon energies (X-ray satellites), resulting in small satellite peaks corresponding to the most intense spectral peaks but displaced by a characteristic energy interval. Therefore, these lines should not be considered in the identification of species in the catalyst sample. Particularly, the spectrum in Fig. S6 shows the satellites corresponding to Mg Kα3 and Kα4 radiation, displaced 8.4 and 10.1 eV to the right of the main peaks and with relative intensities about 8% and 4%, respectively. 3.3.2 Activity tests Fig. 10 shows the acidity of the oily phase as a function of time when the SBA-15 catalysts were tested with and without hydrophobicity modification. The reaction was carried out at 433 K, with an FFA:GOH molar ratio 1:1, and a catalyst loading of 1.2 wt%. Two strategies for adding the catalyst were studied. First, it was added to the GOH, homogenized and then the FFA were dosed. In the second procedure, the catalyst was added in the FFA phase, homogenized and then the GOH was added. The non-modified catalyst SBA(10) performed similarly under both addition protocols, with slightly better activity when added into the glycerine, reaching 80% conversion after approximately 190 min. As it can be observed, changing the hydrophobicity of the catalyst significantly improved the conversion. With the SBA(10)H added to the GOH, 80% conversion was achieved in 150 min, while this time was lowered to 80 min when the catalyst was incorporated to the FFA. Moreover, conversions of the order of 95% were obtained in 3 h of reaction, while with SBA(10) 6 h were required to reach similar conversion levels at the same reaction conditions. This is consistent with the fact that the SBA(10) catalyst has higher affinity for the glycerine phase. Therefore, by changing the hydrophobicity of the solid, it is possible to obtain an amphiphilic character, the catalyst being located at the interface and improving the reaction rate. Furthermore, since the affinity of the catalyst surface for fatty acids was improved with the incorporation of methoxytrimethylsilane groups, the addition of the catalyst in the oil phase significantly improved its activity. Fig. 11 A shows a photograph taken with the optical microscope with 100x amplification of a glycerine-biodiesel mixture with the SBA(10)H catalyst. It can be observed that the catalyst particles are located at the interface but on the biodiesel side. In the case of the SBA(10) catalyst, it was not possible to find particles at the interface. Fig. 11. B and C show photos of biodiesel-glycerine mixtures containing the SBA(10) and SBA(10)H respectively. It can be clearly seen that the catalyst with hydrophobic groups accumulates in the biodiesel phase, while the standard catalyst (SBA(10)) is accumulated in the glycerine phase. These photos also support previous discussion. Fig. 12 shows selected images obtained with the Confocal Microscope. Fig. 12. A and B were obtained with the SBA(10) catalysts, while Fig. 12. C and D correspond to photos obtained with the SBA(10)H. Rhodamine was employed as fluorophore compound, thus dodecane can be observed as a continuous phase with a light pink color, and the pink or red irregular particles correspond to the catalyst. Fig. 12. C and D clearly show that the SBA(10)H particles are located at the interface, in the non-polar side, while in the case of the SBA(10) catalyst, the particles are located in the bulk of the polar phase. No catalyst particles can be found at the interface in this case. Fig. 12. A shows a drop of water of 46.9 micrometers, with particles inside the drop, but not at the interface. In agreement with the photo shown in Fig. 11. A, the particles of SBA(10)H are accumulated at the interface of the polar/non polar phases, on the non-polar side. This evidence supports the better activity previously shown for the hydrophobic catalyst, similarly to what was observed with the PTSA [3]. These results show that the SBA(10)H catalyst, with augmented hydrophobicity, has amphiphilic properties that lead the catalyst particles to be located preferentially at the interface. However, this amphiphilic property is not strong enough in order to stabilize the system forming a Pickering emulsion. Even though it is more effective in favoring the dispersion, it is not stable. Fig. S7 (Supplementary material) shows a photo of water-dodecane mixture, after being mixed with SBA(10) and with SBA(10)H (Fig. S7. A and Fig. S7. B, respectively). It can be observed that in the case of the SBA(10), the catalyst is settled and separated, and the bottom phase is clearer than in the case of the SBA(10)H, indicating a better emulsifier capacity of the hydrophobic catalyst. Regarding the selectivity of the reaction to the glycerides formed and the presence of unidentified secondary reactions, no differences were observed between the experiences carried out with both catalysts (not shown). 3.3.3 Effect of water removal The SBA(10) and SBA(10)H catalysts have been tested in reactions both under vacuum as above described and under reflux conditions, i.e. without water removal. Fig. 13 shows that the reaction rate is higher when removing the water from the system as compared with the reaction under reflux conditions with both catalysts. Comparing the SBA(10) and SBA(10)H under reflux conditions, it can be observed that the hydrophobic catalyst (SBA(10)H) is more active, showing higher reaction rates than the SBA(10) catalyst, particularly when the amount of water in the system increases. This can be inferred looking at the slope of both curves, the values obtained with the SBA(10)H being higher in the 60–240 min interval. This result indicates that the hydrophobic catalyst is favoring the direct reaction, and hindering the inverse reaction due to the repulsion of water, as suggested by other authors [9]. However, in the absence of water the hydrophobic catalyst is also more active than the hydrophilic catalyst. Since the concentration of acid sites is practically the same (1.12 and 1.11 mmol/g for SBA(10) and SBA(10)H, respectively, Table 1), the amphiphilic property of the hydrophobic catalyst is playing an additional important role in improving the overall kinetics in this system. 3.4 Reusability of catalysts Catalyst reusability was tested, using the catalyst SBA(10), loading 3 wt% at 160 ºC for 3 h, under vacuum. After the reaction, the solid was recovered by centrifugation, washed with ethanol and dried at 100 ºC. The catalyst was then reused under the same operating conditions. Fig. 14 shows the FFA concentration over time obtained in three consecutive reaction cycles. The catalyst preserves the activity after the first cycle, and shows a minor loss in activity for the third cycle. The ED-XRF analyses corroborated the preservation of sulfur content in the solids (8.5% S/Si before and after use), ruling out a possible leaching of these active sites. The thermogravimetric analysis of the recovered catalyst (Fig. S8, Supplementary material) showed an additional weight loss compared with the fresh catalyst (Fig. 9), reflected in DTG curve as a peak around 350 ºC, and associated with an exothermic process according to the SDTA curve. Moreover, potentiometric titration showed a partial decrease in acidity. Therefore, the deactivation path is consistent with a fouling process of the solid, produced by the accumulation of high-molecular weight organic by-products. After the first cycle, there are not enough blocked sites to have a significant impact in activity, and the loss becomes more notable after two cycles. 3.5 Nature of secondary products: preliminary studies In a recent publication [3], we presented results regarding the formation of secondary products during the esterification of glycerine with free fatty acids, using sulfuric, p-toluene sulfonic, and methanesulfonic acids as catalysts. As also shown for comparison in Fig. S3, it is evident that the nature of secondary products is different when using homogeneous acid catalysts, as those obtained with the SBA-15 functionalized catalysts. Regarding the dark color development during the reaction, it has been shown that fatty acids can condensate forming estolides that might have dark color depending upon the reaction conditions. Åkerman et al. [27] put oleic acid in contact with a solid acid catalyst (silica impregnated with sulfuric acid) and found that at 70 °C the mixture turned dark. The authors verified the presence of dimeric and trimeric condensation derivatives of oleic acid with a structure of estolides. Cermak and Istbell [28] also studied this reaction, and found that depending upon the carboxylic acids used in the condensation reaction, mixtures with very dark color (18 in the Gardner scale) were obtained. In addition, it was found that fatty acids in the presence of mineral acids such as perchloric acid, form lactones as secondary products when increasing the temperature up to 373 K [29]. The migration of the double bond to position 4 or 5 of the fatty acid leads to the formation of γ- and δ-lactones, respectively [28]. Using a heterogeneous catalyst (layered double hydroxide) in the glycerine esterification reaction with fatty acids, Hamerski et al. [30] found that the reaction media became darker as the reaction temperature increased, but in all cases in the range of light brown-orange, as we also show in Fig. S3 in the present study. However, these authors did not discuss the possible nature of secondary products that may produce such color changes. Other by-products that can be formed in the presence of acid catalysts are polyglycerols and oxygenated heterocyclic compounds [31]. Cheng et al. [32] showed that during the deodorization of vegetable oils at 473–518 K, glycidyl fatty esters can be formed through a reaction that involve mono- or di-glycerides as reactants. However, in the presence of acids the epoxy group is highly unstable and decomposes forming alcohol in the presence of water or hydroxieter in the presence of another alcohol. 3.5.1 FTIR analyses The product of the reaction carried out with SBA(10) at 433 K, containing approximately 40 wt% of secondary products was analyzed by FTIR spectroscopy. The result is shown in Fig. S9 (Supplementary material). Bands assignments are presented in Table S1 (Supplementary material). There is no shift to lower wavenumber of the signal that corresponds to -CH2- bending, suggesting that there are no cyclic aliphatic groups in the sample. In addition, there is no signal between 3080 − 3040 cm−1 that correspond to C-H stretching in cyclopropane [33]. Another conclusion that can be obtained from the result shown in Fig. S9, is that there is no formation of aromatic hydrocarbons, since these compounds display signals in the ranges of 3150–3000 cm−1 (stretching) and 900–690 cm−1, which are not present in the spectrum. It can be inferred, according to these results, that glycidyl fatty esters are not formed under the conditions used in the glycerine esterification reaction with SBA(10). The epoxy ring displays absorption bands at 1263 cm−1 and 991 cm−1 due to symmetrical and asymmetrical stretching. The FTIR spectrum shown in Fig. S9 does not show these signals, and therefore, the glycidyl derivatives are not present as secondary products, at least in significant amounts. The γ- and δ-lactones present absorption bands at 900 cm−1, approximately [34]. Therefore, since there is no signal in the spectrum shown in Fig. S9 at this wavenumber, the presence of these lactones can also be ruled-out. 3.5.2 GC-MS analyses The peaks shown in the GC analysis presented in Fig. S2 (Supplementary material) as secondary products, have been analyzed with the GC-MS technique. Unfortunately, it was not possible to identify any reasonable compound that could be formed in this system. In all cases, compounds with a rather low probability of matching the fragments distribution found in the sample were proposed by the MS library used in this analysis. In general, compounds related to fatty acid esters were proposed, but in many cases, such compounds were not able to be present in this system, such as for example, ethylesters of fatty acids, or silylated compounds. None of the compounds suggested by the mass spectroscopy technique was related to polyglycerols. These results are consistent with the high probability of having estolides with different condensation degrees as the main by-products. A dimeric estolide would have a molecular weight higher than a monoglycerides, and could correspond to the group of peaks indicated in the GC analysis shown in Fig. S2, right after the monoglycerides. The trimeric estolide has a molecular weight higher than the diglyceride and, therefore, the peaks that appear at 25–27 min in the chromatograms (Fig. S2) could correspond to these compounds. Finally, and although more specific work is needed to identify the secondary products without ambiguities, it can be concluded that the estolides with different degree of condensation are presumably the main compounds that lead to a decrease in the yield of the glycerine esterification with fatty acids in the presence of the functionalized SBA-15 catalysts. 4 Conclusions SBA-15 functionalized with propyl sulfonic groups are active catalysts for the esterification of glycerine with FFA, obtaining more than 95% conversion of FFA at 433 K, in less than 6 h depending upon the catalyst concentration. The sulfonic groups were loaded representing 5, 10, and 15 mol% of the silicon precursors. The catalyst in which 10% of these precursors contained sulfonic groups was the most active One. At higher concentration of sulfonic groups, there was a loss of ordering in the structure and, consequently, a lower activity was observed. The concentration of the secondary products increases as a function of time, and when increasing the catalyst loading, reaching values as high as 40 wt%. The nature of these secondary products is different from that obtained with homogenous catalysts. On the one hand, it was possible to observe these compounds in the GC analysis, and on the other hand, the mixture never gets colors as dark as in the case of the latter catalysts. Preliminary analyses carried out combining FTIR and GC-MS analyses suggest that estolides might be the most important secondary products. The functionalized SBA-15 concentrates in the glycerine phase. As the FFA/glycerine ratio increases, the catalyst is more concentrated due to the smaller volume of the glycerine phase, and correspondingly a higher reaction rate is observed. There is a linear correlation in the initial reaction rate with the catalyst concentration in the polar phase. This is a very important concept to take into account when optimizing the reacting system. The homogeneous catalyst (p-toluene sulfonic acid) is 5 times more active per acid site than the SBA(10) catalyst, and also shows better selectivity (lower amount of secondary products). The reason is that the p-toluene sulfonic acid has amphiphilic properties being concentrated at the interface, while the SBA(10) catalyst is concentrated in the bulk of the glycerine phase. The modification of this material making its surface more hydrophobic led to a significant improvement in activity, opening an interesting alternative for a better catalyst design for this reacting system. coredata.dc:description: Mesoporous silica (SBA-15) functionalized with different concentrations of sulfonic groups is used in the esterification of glycerine with fatty acids. This article addresses the effects of temperature, free fatty acids/glycerine ratio and catalyst concentration. It has been shown that high amounts of secondary products may be formed in this reaction system. Accordingly, this work also analyzes the effect of reaction conditions on this yield and presents a comparison with the effect obtained using homogeneous catalysts. Significant amounts of secondary products are also formed with liquid catalysts. The hydrophobic/hydrophilic behavior of the catalysts plays a key role both in the activity and selectivity to the desired products. A catalyst was prepared tuning the hydrophobicity of the surface in order to test this hypothesis, obtaining a higher activity than in the conventional catalyst. These results show the importance of designing catalysts with amphiphilic properties for this system.
coredata.dc:title: Glycerine esterification with free fatty acids using SBA-15 functionalized catalysts: Effect of hydrophobicity
